title: CPU Kernel Mode - Computerphile
description:
"If your name's not down, you're not coming in!" - How the CPU's "Bouncer" keeps some memory off-limits. Matt Godbolt continues the series on low-level computing.
#computerscience  #cpu #computing 

Computerphile is supported by Jane Street. Learn more about them (and exciting career opportunities) at: https://jane-st.co/computerphile

This video was filmed and edited by Sean Riley.

Computerphile is a sister project to Brady Haran's Numberphile. More at https://www.bradyharanblog.com

comments.author: @gidi1899
comments.comment:
Anybody knows about an OS that has "nested kernels" or "nested idle mode" ?!

The Idea is that the PC gets a Role, say "a keyboard mirror", 
 and every Role has idle time, in which it can take on the secondary role of "Application Support",
   in which it can run some other Role as a Sub-Role, and is responsible for it's actions,
   it gaurd the PC from any abuse coming from the sub role.

It's more deterministic and less dynamic than the Real-Time Linux Kernel .

Buttom line, when creating an application for this OS, one must find 
an valid supporting app that will run this app when idle, and one must decide if this app 
can have sub apps, and if so, it is responsible for adding app-support code.
(there is code duplication, but it's ok because it must be maintained separately, and up/down the
 nesting - sharing protocols can be set for code developement)

Just A Thought.

comments.author: @cryptonative
comments.comment: These are great videos but the argument here is missguided, it’s great to have memory protections but it’s a big tradeoff to have the protections hardcoded into the cpu die. It’s a tradeoff for cpu innovation and security when there’s a bug in the cpu design.
